awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: I-AIM: Interpretable Augmented Intelligence for Multiscale Material Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to model, predict, and improve the mechanical performance of engineering materials such as polymers, composites, and alloys can have a significant impact on manufacturing, with important economic and societal benefits. As advanced computational algorithms and data science approaches become available, they can be harnessed to disrupt the current approaches to materials modeling, and allow for the design and discovery of new high-strength, high-performance materials for manufacturing. Bringing together multidisciplinary teams of researchers can maximize the impact of these new tools and techniques. This Harnessing the Data Revolution Institutes for Data-Intensive Research in Science and Engineering (HDR-I-DIRSE) award supports the conceptualization of an Institute to develop novel data science methods, address fundamental scientific questions of Materials Engineering and Manufacturing, and build such multidisciplinary teams. The project will apply novel data science methods to advance the analysis of large sets of structural data of composite materials and alloys from the atomic scale to correlate with and predict mechanical properties. The methods are based on machine learning techniques and uncertainty quantification, and will help uncover underlying structural features in the materials that determine the properties and performance. The methods and results will help accelerate the development of ultra-high strength and lightweight carbon-based composites for aerospace applications, and multi-element superalloys for more durable engine parts, by navigating in the large possible design space and providing faster predictions than experiments and traditional simulation methods. The project will also lead to new methods and computational algorithms that will become publicly available. The investigators will train graduate and undergraduate students from various disciplines with a focus on engaging women and minorities in STEM fields, develop short courses that integrate novel Materials Science and Engineering applications and Data Science methods, and foster vertical integration of interdisciplinary research from undergraduate students to senior scientists.

This project aims at building an effective and interpretable learning framework for materials data across scales to solve a major challenge in current data-driven materials design. The combined Materials Science and Data Science approaches will synergistically contribute to the development and use of interpretable and physics-informed data science methodologies to gain new understanding of mechanical properties of polymer composites and alloys, with the potential to be expanded into different property sets and different systems. The PIs will utilize available data efficiently through combination with physical rules and prior knowledge, to develop an interpretable augmented intelligent system to learn principles behind the association of input structures with material properties with uncertainty quantification. The interconnected tasks involve the (1) collection and curation of large amounts of computational and experimental data for polymer/carbon nanotube composites and alloys from open data sources and targeted calculations and experiments, (2) the development of geometric and topological methods incorporating physical principles to generate a better, more sensitive low-dimensional representation of the multidimensional data and characterize the parameter space related to mechanical properties, (3) the development of a Bayesian deep reinforcement learning framework to generate interpretable knowledge graphs that depict the relational knowledge among physical quantities with uncertainty quantification, and (4) the prediction of mechanical properties to reveal design principles to improve materials performance, evaluate and validate the methods, and develop software for dissemination. 

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity and is co-funded by the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
The project has advanced the development of data science tools and effective, interpretable learning frameworks for materials data and properties at length scales from atoms to microstructures. The outcomes include new machine learning methods based on graph representations and gradient boosted trees to predict mechanical and failure properties of carbon nanostructures and carbon-fiber cross-sections from the 3D atomic structure, using training sets from reactive molecular dynamics simulations (IFF-R). New deep sets models were developed to compute mechanical properties of alloys consisting of multiple different metals, taking advantage of available large databases of alloy properties from quantum mechanical simulations by density functional theory. Several new high-entropy alloys with tunable metastability, phase transformations, and catalytic activity have been discovered supported by thermodynamic modeling and machine learning. Machine-learned property predictions for such new materials are between 10 and 1000 times faster than using traditional simulation methods and have been verified by experimental measurements through collaborations where possible. Furthermore, causal discovery tools were developed to deduce constitutive laws for granular materials, including measures such as the void ratio and fabric tensors. Image-to-prediction workflows to solve mechanics problems could be improved using Morse graphs with more flexible and robust low-dimensional representation of topology generated from micro-CT images. Advanced methods in Bayesian networks help to decipher relationships among physical variables to infer material laws and support designs. A major outcome of this project are new multidisciplinary collaborations and team efforts up to a large scale of about 20 participants with non-traditional combinations of expertise at the intersection of data science and materials science, including computer science, chemistry, materials science, statistics, applied math, and medicine, as documented by publications. The synergistic methods and tools can be used towards further integration of data science and materials science methods to accelerate the design of functional materials and composites in unconventional ways.

The results of this project are documented in over 30 peer-reviewed publications in interdisciplinary areas, including contributions in top machine learning conferences, materials science, biology, chemistry, statistics, computational science, and general science journals. Broader impacts include new ways to predict mechanical properties of carbon nanostructures, high entropy alloys, plasticity of polycrystals, the activity of alloy catalysts for fuel cells ad carbon dioxide reduction, as well as advances in deep sets models, graph neural networks, causal relationships, and sparse regression methods. More than 10 symposia at national meetings and international workshops were organized, as well as a webinar series ?Data Science for Materials Discovery? on Youtube that features advances in data-driven discovery of materials. The investigators delivered over 50 invited presentations, won awards, guest professorships, and were appointed as Editors of impactful journals during the project period. The project supported the training of more than 10 PhD students and 3 postdocs, who obtained competitive fellowships, positions in industry, academia, and government laboratories. More than 10 undergraduate students, several high school students were engaged in summer research programs and, COVID-19 restrictions permitting, the investigators and graduate students held outreach events at local K-12 schools.

 


Last Modified: 01/31/2023
Modified by: Hendrik Heinz

Images (1 of )
  • A workflow for utilizing large datasets, feature representations, and machine learning tools to predict materials properties(from Nature Materials, DOI: 10.1038/s41563-022-01384-1)
    Yusu Wang and Hendrik Heinz
    Copyrighted
    Hendrik Heinz
    Machine learning-aided prediction of materials properties
  • Carbon nanotube bundles in transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and in an atomistic model used to predict mechanical properties using machine learning. The model has much higher resolution than the experimental image, allowing control over the morphology and amount of defects.
    Hendrik Heinz
    Copyrighted
    Hendrik Heinz
    Visualization of carbon nanotube bundles
  • The image shows the correlation of lattice parameters, crystal structure, and bulk modulus of a series of multi-element alloys (high entropy alloys) using large data sets and machine learning (deep sets)
    Wei Chen
    Copyrighted
    Hendrik Heinz
    Properties of high entropy alloys
  • Prediction of tensile strength of carbon nanotube bundles and other graphitic nanostructures using various machine learning methods
    Yusu Wang and Hendrik Heinz
    Copyrighted
    Hendrik Heinz
    Prediction of tensile strength
  • Image of an alloy and the related density of states related to the nitrogen reduction reaction
    Wei Chen
    Copyrighted
    Hendrik Heinz
    Prediction of catalytic properties
  • Machine learning algorithms are used to remove fluctuations and noise from molecular dynamics simulations, allowing to focus more on the underlying physical behavior.
    Wai-Ching (Steve) Sun
    Copyrighted
    Hendrik Heinz
    Workflow to de-noise molecular dynamics simulations
